sect2.title: Introduction
sect2.para: A layer effect is a filter that you can tweak at any time, that doesn't immediately and more-or-less permanently affect a layer.
The advantage is that after many more intervening operations, you can still go back and tweak the layer effect. Unlike Undo, where you might need to Undo and Redo many operations.
Also, after saving and reopening an image, you can still tweak its layer effects.
You add a layer effect just like other filters, by selecting a layer and then choosing a command (a menu item or keyboard shortcut.)

A layer effect is a class of filters. You may not know a menu item creates a layer effect until you choose the menu item and see the
icon in the Layers dialog. Also, when you are adding a filter to an image that will create a layer effect (versus creating a destructive effect), the Filter dialog will have a Merge Filter button. See Common Filter Features.
Most Gegl filters can be layer effects. No non-Gegl filters can be layer effects.
Layer effects only apply to a single layer, while other filters may apply to channels, layers, or entire images.
You can't choose whether a filter can be a layer effect. But you can choose to use a filter that can be a layer effect in a non-tweakable way: see Merging.

sect2.title: Terminology
sect2.para:
Gimp represents layer effects with an icon:
. The icon appears in the Layer dialog, in the row of the layer the layer effect applies to, when you add a layer effect to the layer.
The term fx is an abbreviation for effect.
Layer effects are also known as "non-destructive edits (NDE)." They don't permanently change their layer.
This means they have parameters which you can change at a later time. Changes to parameters immediately cascade into their layer and the entire image.
While all filters have an effect on layers, in the sense of a result, here we intend the words "layer effect" to mean a certain use of certain eligible filters.

sect2.title: Adding a Layer Effect to a Layer
sect2.para:
You create a layer effect by selecting a layer, then choosing a command that is backed by a filter that can be a layer effect. Then the
icon appears next to the layer name in the Layers dialog.

A layer effect belongs to a layer. A layer may have many layer effects, in a stack. When you add a layer effect, it adds to the top of any stack of existing layer effects. You can later move it, using the Layer Effects dialog.
Creating a layer effect is undoable.

sect2.title: Order Matters
sect2.para: The order of layer effects matters. Layer effects are stacked above their layer. The result of a layer effect propagates down to the layer effect underneath it, ultimately to the layer.
You can rearrange the order of layer effects on a layer by choosing a layer effect and then clicking the Up Arrow or Down Arrow buttons in the Layer Effects dialog.
Some changes in order might appear invisible, it depends on the actual layer effects and their parameters.
Reordering layer effects is undoable.

sect2.title: The Layer Effects Dialog
sect2.para: Use this dialog to edit, reorder, remove, or change the visibility of layer effects. You can also use this dialog to merge down all effects on a layer.
You open this dialog by clicking on the fx icon in a row of the Layers dialog.
As you use this dialog, you immediately see the changes to the image.

sect3.title: Selecting a Layer Effect
sect3.para: Click on a row in the Layer Effects dialog to select the effect.

sect3.title: Editing a Layer Effect
sect3.para:
Choose the Edit Layer Effects button/icon after you select an effect.
The dialog for the filter will appear. Change its parameters. You will immediately see any changes to the image. When you are done, choose the OK button. After you choose OK, the tweaks are not undoable, but you can tweak them again later.
When you choose the Cancel button/icon of the filter's dialog, any tweaks you have made are reverted.

sect3.title: Removing a Layer Effect
sect3.para:
Select a layer effect row. Then choose the Remove Layer Effects button/icon.
The layer effect row will disappear. When it is the last effect on the layer, the dialog will also close.
Removing a layer effect is undoable.

sect3.title: Reordering Layer Effects
sect3.para:
Choose the Move Up or Move Down button/icon.
The layer effect row will move up or down.
Reordering a layer effect is undoable.

sect3.title: Changing the Visibility of a Layer Effect
sect3.para:
Choose the Visibility button/icon.
The effect on the image will show or hide.
Changing the visibility of a layer effect is not undoable, like changing the parameters of the effect.

sect3.title: Merging All Layer Effects
sect3.para:
Choose the Merge Down button/icon.
The rows in the dialog will disappear. The Layer Effects dialog will close.
You can undo Merging Down. Choose the "Undo Rasterizing filters" item from the Undo menu. That will restore the layer effects on the layer. But it will not undo the changes to the image!

sect3.title: Closing the Layer Effects Dialog
sect3.para: There is no Cancel button to cancel any changes you have made, but while the dialog is open you can reverse some changes , and after you close the dialog you can undo some changes.

sect2.title: Merging
sect2.para: When you choose a menu item that can be a layer effect, you can choose to use the filter in a non-tweakable way. This is called "Merging", similar to the way you merge layers.

To use a filter in a non-tweakable way, when you see the filter's dialog, choose the "Merge Filter" checkbox. Then, after choosing "OK", the filter has a non-tweakable result on the layer, and no new layer effect is pushed atop the stack of layer effects.

You can still Undo what you did, or do it again with different choices. But it won't appear in the stack of layer effects. And if you subsequently do other operations, it will be harder to undo than if you use the filter as a layer effect.

sect2.title: Merging and Auxiliary Other Images
sect2.para: Some filters take two images, the active image and another "auxiliary" image, which you must separately choose in the filter's dialog. The auxiliary image may be called for example a "bump map" or a "mask."
Such a filter's dialog will have "Merge Filter" checkbox checked and disabled. This means that the filter won't become a layer effect.
We anticipate that in the future, filters that take auxiliary other images might be tweakable and appear as layer effects.

sect2.title: Undo and Layer Effects
sect2.para: You can undo adding or removing a layer effect.

You cannot use the Undo menu item to revert changing the parameters of a layer effect. Instead, just keep changing the parameters from your own memory. To record a set of parameter values, you can save them as a preset, the same as for other filters. See Filter Presets.

sect2.title: Persistence of Layer Effects
sect2.para: Layer effects are saved when you save an image in the XCF format. All the presets for a layer effect are also saved.
Layer effects are NOT saved, but "merged", when you export an image to another format. You don't have a choice in the matter when exporting.
For now, layer effects are not saved even in formats which also support layer effects, such as the PSD format.

sect2.title: Filter Presets Dialog
sect2.para: A preset is a template. You apply a preset to an application, or instance, of the filter. That initializes the filter instance. Thereafter you may change the instance settings, but that does not change the preset. Thereafter, you may edit the preset, but that does not change any prior uses of the preset (doesn't change any existing instances.)
A filter preset is for a particular filter. Each filter may have a set of presets.
A filter preset belongs to a filter, not to its instances. You apply, or reapply, a filter preset to an instance of a filter.
Each filter has defaults. But defaults are not the same as presets. A filter may have no presets, until you add them.
You use this dialog to choose and apply an existing preset, or to add a new one, or to edit a preset, or to remove a preset.
Filter presets are named.
